Solvent-free selective oxidation of CH bonds of toluene and substituted toluene to aldehydes by vanadium-substituted polyoxometalate catalyst Baochun Ma ⁎ Zhenxin Zhang Wenfeng Song Xiaoling Xue Yongze Yu Zhensheng Zhao Yong Ding ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 931 8619200; fax: +86 931 8912582. Graphical abstract Highlights ► A homogeneous vanadium-substituted polyoxometalate catalyst was prepared. ► This catalyst showed good activity for oxidation of toluene and substituted toluene. ► A free radical mechanism was proposed based on the experimental results. A novel homogeneous vanadium-substituted polyoxometalate catalyst of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] showed good catalytic activity for the activation of CH bonds of toluene and substituted toluene with TBHP (70% aq) under solvent-free conditions. Under the optimal conditions, a 65% yield of benzaldehyde and a TON of 5221 were obtained over this catalyst at 343K. This catalyst also showed good conversion and selectivity for the oxidation of a series of substituted toluene. The vanadium-substituted Keggin-POM was not decomposed to some species upon the treatment of 530-fold of TBHP by IR characterization. A free radical mechanism was proposed based on the experimental results and the literature supports. Keywords Polyoxometalates Toluene Benzylic CH bonds Benzaldehyde Oxidation 1 Introduction Direct functionalization of hydrocarbons by catalytic oxidation of CH bonds to form oxygenated products under mild conditions is a major challenge in view of industrial aspects [1]. Toluene and substituted toluene, as a kind of the hydrocarbons, are used as the most important precursors of various fine chemicals. For toluene, the oxygenated products mainly include benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde and benzoic acids. Among these products, benzaldehyde is the most desirable products. However, benzaldehyde is easily transformed to corresponding carboxylic acid due to over oxidation. By traditional method, benzaldehyde can be yielded by side-chain chlorination of toluene followed by saponification of the resulting dichloromethyl group to form the aldehyde [2]. However, the product generated by this method contains the chlorinated by-products, which do not meet food and drug grade specifications. Another method of oxidizing toluene is vapor phase oxidation with oxygen but the reaction is carried out at high pressure and high temperature and seems too harsh for improving the selectivity of benzaldehyde [3]. Until now, catalytic oxidation systems in liquid phase for toluene and substituted toluene were limited to a few examples such as iridium (III) chloride [4], metal complexes [5], 10-methyl-9-phenylacridinium ion [6], xanthone [7] as homogeneous catalysts; supported metal complexes [8] and metal containing molecular sieves [9] as heterogeneous catalyst. Although many procedures for the catalytic oxidation toluene and substituted toluene in liquid have been developed, most of them suffered the low yield of benzaldehyde or the low selectivity to benzaldehyde or the difficulty for the recovery of the catalyst. Therefore, developing new pathway to oxidize the toluene and substituted toluene under mild condition and improving the yield of aldehyde are of great demand and importance. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are molecular metal-oxygen clusters with discrete structures and they have led to many applications in various areas. The application of POMs to catalysis has attracted much attention, and the versatility and accessibility of POMs have been used to various catalytic oxidation process, such as olefin epoxidation [10], alcohol oxidation [11] and pyridine oxidation [12]. However, only few research concerns on oxidation of toluene and substituted toluene using POMs as catalysts under mild condition [2,13] and the catalytic activity of the catalysts is low and the selectivity to aldehyde is not satisfied, either. Recently, Mizuno and co-workers reported a divanadium-substituted phosphotungstate that catalyses the stereo- and regioselective hydroxylation of alkanes with hydrogen peroxide as the sole oxidant [14]. Although the catalyst showed high activity for catalytic oxidation of CH bonds of cyclic akkanes, other types of CH bonds such as benzylic CH bonds are not investigated in their publication. Here, we reported a tri-vanadium-substituted phosphotungstate, [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] (I), as efficient homogeneous catalyst for direct activate the CH bonds of toluene and substituted toluene with tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oxidant under solvent-free conditions. For the first time, the catalyst was used to catalyze oxidation of toluene and substituted toluene. These compounds could be converted to corresponding aldehyde in high yields, and thousands of catalytic turnovers were obtained. A 65% yield of benzaldehyde and a TON of 5221 were obtained over this catalyst, which was the highest value among those reported for TBHP-based catalytic system so far [4–9]. These vanadium-substituted polyoxometalates catalysts were characterized by FT-IR, 31P NMR, TGA and elemental analysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All materials used were of analytical reagent grade and used without further purification unless otherwise stated. 2.2 Characterization techniques Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet FT-IR-360 FT-IR spectrometer. The catalysts were measured using 2–4% (w/w) KBr pellets prepared by manual grinding. 31P NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Unity-300MHz NMR spectrometer, using DMSO-d 6 as the solvent; 31P MAS NMR spectra were recorded at 9.4T on a Bruker Avance-400 wide bore spectrometer. The 31P MAS NMR spectra of solid catalyst with high-power proton decoupling were performed at 161.9MHz with BB MAS probe head using 4mm ZrO2 rotors and 3.8μs pulse and 2s repetition time and 4096 scans, with samples spun at 10kHz and referenced to 85% H3PO4. Chemical elemental analysis of the catalysts was done on an ICP atomic emission spectrometer (IRIS ER/S), and C, H, and N contents were measured on a German Elementar Vario EL spectrometer. TGA was recorded on Perkin Elmer PE7. GC analyses were performed on Shimadzu GC-9AM with a flame ionization detector equipped with SE-54 capillary (internal diameter=0.25mm, length=30m). GC–MS were recorded on Finnigan Trace DSQ (Thermo Electron Corporation) at an ionization voltage of 70eV equipped with a DB-5 capillary column (internal diameter=0.25mm, film thickness=0.25lm, length=30m). 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AM-400 and Varian mercury 300MHz spectrometer with TMS as an internal standard and CDCl3 as solvent. 2.3 Synthesis of polyoxometalates 2.3.1 Na8H[ΔPW9O34][15a] Firstly, Na2WO4·2H2O (30.0g, 91mmol) was dissolved in 37mL of distilled water. After adding 85% H3PO4 (0.75mL, 12mmol), 5.5mL of glacial acetic acid was added to the solution with stirring. After a few seconds the solution became cloudy and about 1min later a heavy white precipitate had formed. The obtained solid was first dried under aspiration for 24h, and then the aspirated solid was left in air for 24h. After that, the resulting solid was dried at 140°C for about 1.5h. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 1171, 1057, 994, 947, 896, 818, 742, 653, 624, 588, 507, 470, 417. 2.3.2 [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] NaVO3 (1.3mmol) was dissolved in 13mL of hot water. On cooling, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.0 with 3M HCl. Cs6[PW9V3O40] (0.4g, 0.12mmol) was dissolved in the solution and the insoluble materials were removed by filtration. Tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (0.2g, 0.61mmol) was added with vigorous stirring. The precipitate was collected by filtration, washed 3 times with water, and dried under high vacuum. 31P NMR (DMSO-d 6): −13.7ppm. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3497, 2961, 2936, 2873, 2735, 1633, 1482, 1381, 1152, 1106, 1087, 1054, 957, 884, 800, 597, 515, 449. Calcd for [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40]: C, 17.96; H, 3.46; N, 1.31. Found: C, 17.95; H, 3.71; N, 1.28. 2.3.3 [n-Bu4N]4H[PW10V2O40] [14] Cs5[PV2W10O40] was synthesized according to published literature procedures and characterized by infrared spectroscopy [20]. The tetra-n-butylammonium salt of the monoprotonated deritived [n-Bu4N]4H[PW10V2O40] was prepared using a cation-exchange reaction. NaVO3 (0.4mmol) was dissolved in 40mL hot water. On cooling, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.0 with 3M HCl. Cs5[PV2W10O40] (1.27g, 0.37mmol) was dissolved in the solution and the insoluble materials removed by filtration. Tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (0.6g, 1.8mmol) was added with vigorous stirring. The precipitate was collected by filtration, washed 3 times with 130mL water, and dried under high vacuum. 31P NMR (DMSO-d 6): −14.30ppm. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 1096, 1062, 1040, 1000, 953, 871, 805, 751, 534, 488. 2.3.4 [n-Bu4N]4[PW11VO40] K4[PW11VO40] was synthesized according to published literature procedure [16] and characterized by IR spectroscopy. The tetra-n-butylammonium salt of the [n-Bu4N]4 [PW11VO40] was prepared as follows: The yellow solid (1g, 0.34mmol) of K4[PW11VO40] was dissolved in 20mL of distilled water under stirring at room temperature. To this solution tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (0.55g, 1.7mmol) was added. The mixture was stirred vigorously and acidified by one drop of HCl (conc.). Acidification initiated precipitation of quaternary ammonium salt of POM. The precipitate was filtered off, washed 3 times with water, and dried under high vacuum. 31P NMR (DMSO-d 6): −14.18ppm. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 1099, 1077, 983, 883, 790, 596, 521. K6H[SiW9V3O40]·3H2O was synthesized according to published literature procedure [16] and characterized by IR spectroscopy. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 1008, 958, 914, 798. 2.3.5 [n-Bu4N]6H[SiW9V3O40] K6H[SiW9V3O40] (0.5g, 0.18mmol) was dissolved in 50mL of distilled water under stirring at room temperature. To this solution tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (1.4g, 4.3mmol) was added. The mixture was stirred vigorously and acidified by one drop of HCl (conc.). Acidification initiated precipitation of quaternary ammonium salt of POM. The precipitate was filtered off, washed 3 times with water, and dried under high vacuum. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 1005, 956, 914, 796. 2.3.6 Cs6[PW9V3O40] [16] NaVO3 (0.61g, 5mmol) was added to 20mL (1.0M) of sodium acetate/acetic acid buffered at pH=4.8. Then, 4g of Na8H[ΔPW9O34] (1.66mmol) was added to the above solution and stirred at 25°C for 48h. To This solution, a saturated solution of CsCl was added, until no further precipitation occurred. The product was filtered and washed with 2×20mL of 25°C water. Then the solid was dried in air to give 4.6g of tan-orange powder. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 1085, 1055, 962, 876, 788, 597, 509, 481. 31P MAS NMR: −13.3ppm. 2.4 Catalytic reaction A acetonitrile solution of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] (80mg of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] in 100mL acetonitrile) was firstly prepared. The catalytic reaction was performed in a round-bottomed flask equipped with an oil bath, a magnetic stirring bar and a reflux condenser. The oxidation was carried out as follows: catalyst (0.02mM) in 0.25mL acetonitrile, toluene (8.3M, 2.7mL), TBHP (70%, 167mM) were charged in the reaction vessel. The reaction was carried out at 343K was monitored by TLC. The reaction solution was periodically sampled by syringe and analyzed by a Shimadzu GC-9AM with a flame ionization detector equipped with SE-54 capillary (internal diameter=0.25mm, length=30m). Assignments of products were made by comparison with the retention time of authentic reference compounds. The products were identified by GC in combination with mass spectrometry and NMR spectra with those of authentic samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the FT-IR spectra of the obtained POMs catalysts. The characteristic bands of [PW9V3O40]6− are at 1087, 1054, 957, 884, 800, 597, 515, 449cm−1 [15], in which are similar to the previously reported data for the same POM anion. The FT-IR spectrum indicated that the POM anion of [PW9V3O40]6− was retained after forming the tetrabutylammonium salt and cesium salt. The spectrum of 31P NMR gave the detailed structure information of the synthesized I. Only one signal was found at −13.75ppm (Fig. 2a), which demonstrated that the pure single structure of [PW9V3O40]6− was obtained after formation of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40]. 3.2 Catalytic performance of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] as a new homogeneous catalyst was applied to the oxidation of benzylic CH bonds of toluene and its derivatives with TBHP. Several experiments were carried out to test the catalytic activity of I. In reactions performed by the procedure as described in the experimental section, oxidation of toluene and its derivatives to corresponding aldehydes was quite effective. Stoichiometry of the reaction in case of benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol could be given by Eqs. (a) and (b). Selectivity, Yield and TON were determined by gas chromatography using an internal standard technique and were based on TBHP. Reaction conditions of oxidation of benzylic CH bonds were studied and optimized using toluene as a model substrate. Several kinds of POMS were applied to the oxidation of toluene with TBHP. The results (Table 1 ) showed the catalyst of I behaved as the most effective catalyst for the oxidation of toluene. A 65% yield of benzaldehyde was achieved and TON was 5221 (entry 1). It can be observed that vanadium existing in the polyoxometalates had effect on the catalytic performance. The more vanadium existed in polyoxometalate, the catalyst performed more effective (entries 1–3). Concerning the same numbers of vanadium in the polyoxometalate, the one whose heteroatom is silicon showed a poorer activity than that of POM whose heteroatom is phosphorus (entry 4). Some other vanadium-substituted polyoxometalates with the cation of K+, H+ and Cs+ were also investigated (entries 5–9), such as K6[PW9V3O40]·4H2O, K6H[SiW9V3O40]·3H2O, H5PMo10V2O40, K5[PW10V2O40] and Cs6[PW9V3O40]. However, these polyoxometalates showed lower activity (yield=9%, 19%, 12%, 13%, 10%, respectively) compared with the corresponding POMs whose cations were quaternary ammonium ([n-Bu4N]+). The solubility of POMs containing quaternary ammonium as cations is far better than those POMs containing K+, so the catalytic activity of former is better than the latter's. Using the lacunary without vanadium-substituted or saturated polyoxometalates, Na8HPW9O34, H4SiW12O40 and H3PW12O40, the yields were poor (entries 10–12). For simple salt containing vanadium such as NaVO3, the catalytic activity was bad and only 7% of yield was obtained (entry 13). A simple mixture of Na8HPW9O34 and NaVO3 showed low catalytic activity too (entry 14). There was no benzaldehyde was detected when no catalyst was added to the reaction (entry 15). Based on the catalytic results, I was the best catalyst for the oxidation of toluene under the reaction conditions. Some oxidants were studied for the oxidation of toluene catalyzed by I. Different types of peroxides, such as TBHP, di-tert-butyl peroxide (DTBP), hydrogen peroxide, were used to this reaction. However, only TBHP can oxidize toluene to benzaldehyde with high selectivity and yield (entry 1). Oxygen (1atm) does not work at all (entry 18), which autooxidation reaction was ruled out. Thus, the best oxidant for oxidation of toluene was TBHP. No any products were detected when only catalyst I was added to the toluene without oxidant (entry 19). The effect of reaction temperature on the activity of oxidation of toluene was investigated. Reactions were carried out at various temperatures, 283, 303, 333, 358 and 373K (Fig. 3 ). With increasing temperature, the activity of the reaction was gradually increased. When the reaction was carried out at 283K and 303K, although the selectivity to benzaldehyde was high (303K, 99%), the activity of the catalyst was poor (303K, yield=4%; 298K, yield=0). Increasing the reaction temperature result in the oxidation of toluene faster, while the selectivity of aldehyde decreased and the selectivity to benzyl alcohol increased (Fig. 3c). When the reaction was carried out at 343K, the reaction rate markedly increased. A 65% yield of benzaldehyde was achieved after 6h at 343K. Although further increasing the temperature was beneficial for the improvement of the conversion, its magnitude was quite limited and the selectivity of benzaldehyde dropped. Therefore, 343K was suitable for oxidation of toluene using I as catalyst. The amount of the catalyst had effect on the oxidation of toluene. Fig. 4 shows the catalytic performance of toluene oxidation under the condition of different catalyst loadings. With increasing of the amount of I, the conversion of toluene increased while the selectivity of aldehyde decreased. When the catalyst amount increased to 1.2mol‰, the improvement of the conversion and selectivity was quite limited. Although using more catalyst led to higher conversion, but it made the TON smaller and the catalyst thriftless. Therefore, a 0.12mol‰ of catalyst loading afforded satisfied conversion and selectivity and a high TON. Consequently, 0.12mol‰ of catalyst was used for later experiment. The solubility of I in the present reaction solution (toluene as both reactant and solvent) was not high. When a high loading (1.2mol‰) of catalyst was added to the reaction, some of the catalyst became insoluble. In order to confirm the catalytic system was homogeneous, hot separation of catalyst experiment with high catalyst loading (12mol‰) was carried out as follows: A half of the reaction mixture was filtrated to separate the insoluble catalyst of I after 1.5h. The filtrate of the catalyst was quickly transferred into a fresh flask that had been thermally stabilized in the same oil bath and was heated at 343K. Meanwhile, the remaining sample was left to be heated at the same temperature. The oxidation reaction of filtrate and the remaining sample were continued and were monitored by GC. Within the next 2.5h reaction time, both the filtrate and the remaining sample afforded further conversion of toluene, which suggested there existed active species in the filtrate (Fig. 5 ). Compared with the filtrate, a 5% higher conversion of toluene was found in the remaining sample, indicating that the insoluble part of the catalyst could also catalyze the oxidation of toluene. 3.3 Oxidation of substituted toluene What happens for the alkyl benzene with electron-donating group and the one with electron-withdrawing group in this catalytic oxidation system? The catalyst of I was applied to oxidation of other types of alkyl benzene with TBHP at 343K. The results in Table 2 show that I effectively catalyze the oxidation of various alkyl benzene with electron-donating groups, good yield (∼80%) and selectivity (∼90%) to the corresponding aldehydes were obtained (entries 1–5). Thousands of TONs were got under the reaction conditions. It is found that the ring-substituent group could affect activity of the reaction. For the toluene derivatives which had electron donating group, the reaction rate was faster than that of toluene, and the reaction was almost completed in 4h. Another toluene derivative of p-methoxy-toluene containing the electron donating group of methoxy also showed the similar high reaction rate and conversion except for a relative lower selectivity to 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (73%, entry 6). The reason should be ascribed to the high reactivity of electron donating group of methoxy. Thus, the substrate were oxidized to some other products (alcohol and carboxylic acid) besides 4-methoxybenzaldehyde. For ethyl benzene, the methyl group could not be oxygenated; only benzylic CH bonds were oxidized to the carbonyl compound (entry 7) with high yield (95%) and selectivity (96%) to acetophenone. For those toluene derivatives containing electron-withdrawing group, the activity was less than that of the ones having electron-donating groups. The electron withdrawing group made the benzene ring electron deficient and inactivate. So, it was harder for them to be oxidized. p-Chlorotoluene gave a 89% selectivity to 4-chlorobenzaldehyde and a 52% yield (entry 8). The toluene derivative of o-nitro-toluene which has a more stronger electron withdrawing group of nitro-group gave a poor reactivity; a 92% selectivity to 2-nitrobenzaldehyde and a 23% yield were obtained after 6h (entry 9). 3.4 Mechanism for the toluene oxidation The catalysts of the traditional catalytic systems based on phosphorus-contained POMs with peroxide are reported to be decomposed to some phosphatooxotungstate peroxo fragments [17] or some vanadatooxotungstate peroxo species [12c,14,18], which actually catalyzed the oxidation of organic compounds. However, this is not the case for [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] based on the characterization and catalytic experiments. This vanadium-substituted POM was treated with 530-fold of TBHP for 24h (Fig. 1d), which showed the same IR bands as that of the fresh POM. The characteristic bands in FT-IR of phosphatooxotungstate and vanadatooxotungstate species were not found, indicating that phosphatooxotungstate or vanadatooxotungstate fragments did not generated by treating [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] with TBHP. Therefore, there should exist other pathway for the oxidation of toluene mediated by I with TBHP. In order to clarify the reaction mechanism of this catalytic oxidation process, we did the following experiments: At the beginning of the oxidation, the addition of radical scavenger 2,6-di-tert-buty-4-methylphenol (BHT, 370 equivalent with respect to catalyst of I) completely stopped the oxidation, no any products were detected. When the radical scavenger was added to the reaction system after 2h, the conversion of toluene just reached 46%. When the reaction time was prolonged, the conversion and the selectivity kept constant without any change, which differed to the toluene oxidation catalyzed by I without the addition of radical scavenger. For the normal oxidation, the conversion of toluene increased with reaction time continued. All these data showed the oxidation was underwent a free-radical mechanism (see Fig. 6 ). Based on our experiments and previous researches of toluene oxidation with TBHP [2,8c,19], a proposed reaction mechanism was shown in Scheme 1 , in which suggested that two kinds of radicals existed for the present catalytic system. To begin with, the polyoxometalate I (a) reacted with TBHP to form [n-Bu4N]3H3[PV3W9O40(OH)] (b) and the first type of radical of t-BuO. Then the t-BuO reacted with TBHP to generate another radical of t-BuOO. Benzyl radical was produced by the reaction between t-BuOO and toluene. The benzyl radical then combined with the catalyst intermediate of peroxo species [n-Bu4N]3H3[PV3W9O40(OOt-Bu)] (c) to form benzaldehyde. The peroxo species of c was vanadium based peroxide species [14], so vanadium content had positive effect on the reaction activity. The procedure of formation of benzyl alcohol was transferring an electron from benzyl radical to another catalyst intermediate of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PV3W9O40(OH)] (b) to form benzyl cation. At the same time, catalyst was regenerated to the original form of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] (I or a). Finally, the benzyl cation reacts with hydroxyl anion to yield benzyl alcohol. According to the proposed mechanism, two experimental phenomena could be explained. First, although benzaldehyde was the oxygenated product of benzyl alcohol, the mechanism indicated the pathway of forming benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol was independent. Toluene was not initially oxidized to form benzyl alcohol, which then generated benzaldehyde. The experiment showed the same result. The temperature–time curve (Fig. 3b and c) showed that at the beginning of the reaction no benzyl alcohol was produced and benzaldehyde dominated the main product. With the reaction time continuing, the by-product of benzyl alcohol increased immediately in 1h. Then, during the whole 7h reaction duration, the selectivity between benzaldehyde (83%) and benzyl alcohol (16%) nearly kept constant. Second, there existed some intermediate species such as benzyl radical and benzyl cation. The existence of these species answered for the product distribution of ethyl benzene oxidation (Table 2, entry 7), in which only benzylic CH bond could be oxidized. It is well known that benzylic radical or cation was more stable than methylic radical or cation. 4 Conclusions In summary, we developed an effective catalytic system based on a vanadium substituted polyoxometalate, [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40], for oxidation of toluene and toluene derivatives under solvent free conditions. Toluene and substituted toluene could be converted to the corresponding aldehydes under mild conditions (343K, 4–6h) with high selectivity and yield. Only 0.12mol‰ of catalyst was needed for the reaction and up to 7665 (ethyl benzene) of TONs were achieved. Based on our experiments and previous researches of toluene oxidation, a reaction mechanism was proposed, in which two kinds of radicals existed for the present catalytic system. coredata.dc:description: A novel homogeneous vanadium-substituted polyoxometalate catalyst of [n-Bu4N]3H3[PW9V3O40] showed good catalytic activity for the activation of CH bonds of toluene and substituted toluene with TBHP (70% aq) under solvent-free conditions. Under the optimal conditions, a 65% yield of benzaldehyde and a TON of 5221 were obtained over this catalyst at 343K. This catalyst also showed good conversion and selectivity for the oxidation of a series of substituted toluene. The vanadium-substituted Keggin-POM was not decomposed to some species upon the treatment of 530-fold of TBHP by IR characterization. A free radical mechanism was proposed based on the experimental results and the literature supports.
coredata.dc:title: Solvent-free selective oxidation of CH bonds of toluene and substituted toluene to aldehydes by vanadium-substituted polyoxometalate catalyst
